training_organizations.name: Mississippi Department of Child Protection Services – Professional Development
training_organizations.description: MDCPS manages an internal professional development program to train its workforce. Mississippi’s new frontline workers attend training that covers state policy, the legal framework (Youth Court Act), and core skills like safety planning and risk assessment. The Professional Development unit also works with partners like universities (e.g., training through Southern Miss and Jackson State) to deliver ongoing skill-building for staff.

training_organizations.name: Mississippi Child Welfare Institute (Jackson State University)
training_organizations.description: An academic institute at Jackson State University focused on child welfare research and training. It collaborates with MDCPS to prepare social work students for child welfare careers (Title IV-E stipend program) and provides in-service training and conferences. The Institute is aimed at developing a well-trained child welfare workforce knowledgeable about Mississippi’s communities and challenges.

training_organizations.name: Canopy Children’s Solutions
training_organizations.description: A Mississippi-based nonprofit (formerly Mississippi Children’s Home Services) that provides a range of child welfare-related services. Under contract with MDCPS, Canopy operates therapeutic foster care programs, provides behavioral health services to families involved with CPS, and offers a crisis shelter. This allows Mississippi to serve children with specialized needs (like intensive mental health care) in partnership with a private provider.

perpetrator_relationships.relationship: Victim Was Child of Boyfriend or Girlfriend

policies.TribalFoster: Yes, Tribes within state provide foster care
policies.FatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.Def_Subtype_Abuse: Abuse includes mental injury, sexual abuse, sexual exploitation, emotional abuse, nonaccidental other maltreatment, and human trafficking
policies.Def_Subtype_Neglect: Neglect includes educational, medical neglect, and inadequate supervision
policies.NearFatalitiesReview: Yes, reviews are required for all or some cases
policies.InvestReq_OtherSpecify: Notify tribal partners; Physical assessment of victim for evidence of abuse/neglect; Photographs of the child, child's home, or location of residence to document any physical evidence of abuse/neglect; Video recording is also allowed; Drug and alcohol screening may be requested. Referral to a Children's Advocacy Center.
policies.ScreenReq_OtherSpecify: Provide a copy of report to the county youth court and/or prosecutor, district attorney, and law enforcement; When a report of maltreatment in an out-of-home setting is received, the Intake Worker shall ascertain from the reporter whether the alleged perpetrator is the parent, guardian, custodian, person responsible for the child's care or support, or an adult relative or household member with access to the child. If the child is in foster care, the report is screened in and assigned to a Special Investigations Unit (SIU). The Intake Supervisor should notify the law enforcement agency in whose jurisdiction the reported act occurred, as well as any relevant licensing agencies. After the report of Abuse, Neglect, and Exploitation is screened, the county Intake Supervisor/SIU Bureau Director shall refer the report to the district attorney's office and the youth court in whose jurisdiction the act is alleged to have occurred by phone and email.
policies.ScreenInfo_OtherSpecify: If the child has been harmed or is in immediate risk of being harmed
policies.DefHarm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Definition of neglect and its subtypes is defined by the child's lack of care; Definition of abuse refers to causing or allowing the cause of specific injury types; Definition of sexual abuse refers to harm or threat of harm
policies.DefPerp_VaryByTypeSpecify: For neglect and abuse, the perpetrator is any person responsible for the child's care or support; For trafficking, the perpetrator is any person, without regard to the relationship of the person to the child
policies.InvestReq_OtherCases_Specify: Notifying Tribal partners is required if Tribal partners are involved in the case; Physical assessment of victim is required for all; Photographs and videos require permission; Drug and alcohol screening may be requested if drug/alcohol abuse is suspected; Referral to Children's Advocacy Center required depending on the nature of the allegations
policies.ScreenReq_OtherCases_Specify: All screened in reports are sent to the county youth court. Felony reports are sent to the county youth court/prosecutor/district attorney and law enforcement; If abuse occurred in out-of-home setting, referral made to law enforcement
policies.DefMal_Harm_VaryByTypeSpecify: Definition of neglect does not include harm or risk of harm; Definition of abuse includes harm; Definition of sexual abuse includes harm or risk of harm
policies.InvestReq_MHEvalCases_Specify: When there are specific allegations indicating injury which can be corroborated and verified by an examination
policies.ScreenRiskAssess_OtherSpecify: No specific tool is mentioned; Determination is made whether the child is in imminent risk of harm or the presence of life-threatening harm
policies.InvestReq_MedEvalCases_Specify: When there are specific allegations indicating injury which can be corroborated and verified by an examination
policies.InvestReq_PerpInterviewCase_Spec: Required for all cases, unless law enforcement requests that they not be interviewed
policies.ScreenReq_RiskAssessCase_Specify: Only cases that meet the statutory criteria of maltreatment (e.g., Level II and III cases)
